text: When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

I thought that there was a lot of hubub on the news, but I didn't know what it was all about until I sat down to really pay attention. "It's a tragedy!" the newscaster was gasping.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

I thought that there was a lot of hubub on the news, but I didn't know what it was all about until I sat down to really pay attention. "It's a tragedy!" the newscaster was gasping. "The government has been hiding the side effects of the immortality drug for decades!

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

I thought that there was a lot of hubub on the news, but I didn't know what it was all about until I sat down to really pay attention. "It's a tragedy!" the newscaster was gasping. "The government has been hiding the side effects of the immortality drug for decades!" I settled into my seat, feeling my knees creak and hearing my joints audibly pop. I winced. I'd always half felt sorry for myself that I was too old for the drug, but the other half of me knew, just knew that the other shoe would drop some day. I sighed and adjusted my pillow behind my aching back as I turned up the volume to listen. My ear weren't what they used to be.

"They're pulling the drug immediately!" the newscaster was almost shrieking, and I could see her panic. "They say the effects of the drug will wear off exactly 58 years after they were first administered!" I could see the shock and disbelief of her atrifically young face. "We're all going to get...old!" SHe could barely get teh word out. Like it was a curse.

"They're pulling the drug immediately!" the newscaster was almost shrieking, and I could see her panic. "They say the effects of the drug will wear off exactly 58 years after they were first administered!" I could see the shock and disbelief of her terrifically youthful face. "We're all going to get...old!" She could barely get the word out. Like it was a curse. I felt a twinge of pity for her. Here I'd had my whole like to settle into myself and get used to the aches and pains, to get comfortable with the notion of my own mortality. These younger people who had lived their whole lives feeling immortal They were about to hit a hard reality.

"They say the effects of the drug will wear off exactly 58 years after they were first administered!" I could see the shock and disbelief of her terrifically youthful face. "We're all going to get...old!" She could barely get the word out. Like it was a curse. I felt a twinge of pity for her. Here I'd had my whole like to settle into myself and get used to the aches and pains, to get comfortable with the notion of my own mortality. These younger people who had lived their whole lives feeling immortal They were about to hit a hard reality.

I turned off the TV and settled back into my chair. This would change everything, I realized. There would be repercussions all through society. People who had put off having kids because they had all the time in the world suddenly had no time. There weren't many kids around, I realized. The world could be in for a whole lot of trouble if its whole work force suddenly aged out of their ablilty to work. My dawning sense of dread was only slightly assuaged by the fact that I was too old to really feel the repercussions of this.

"We're all going to get...old!" She could barely get the word out. Like it was a curse. I felt a twinge of pity for her. Here I'd had my whole like to settle into myself and get used to the aches and pains, to get comfortable with the notion of my own mortality. These younger people who had lived their whole lives feeling immortal They were about to hit a hard reality.

I turned off the TV and settled back into my chair. This would change everything, I realized. There would be repercussions all through society. People who had put off having kids because they had all the time in the world suddenly had no time. There weren't many kids around, I realized. The world could be in for a whole lot of trouble if its whole work force suddenly aged out of their ablilty to work. My dawning sense of dread was only slightly assuaged by the fact that I was too old to really feel the repercussions of this. I'd be dead before it really got bad. I pressed the button on my phone to call the assistant in my home. I loved it here, I mused, as I waited for her to respond. THis retirement community was the perfect place to hide out and live my last decade or two in peace. I pushed the button again. And again. Finally I called the front desk. A harried voice answered. 

"Unless it's an emergency," the woman squawked at me, "nobody's coming! Everyone left!" I sat up. "What did you say?" THe dread was spreading through me like a nagging fever in my bones. "They left!" She repeated. "They all realized they have one more year to live as 26 year old; nobody wanted to be stuck here for the last good year they have left!"

"But you're still here," I tried to argue, although I heard the wvering in my own voice. 

"I'll be outta here as soon as I find my purse," she said distractedly. "Sorry, pal. You're on your own."

And then I realized that everything was about to change for the worse, and not just for the fools who tried to make themselves young forever.

"We're all going to get...old!" She could barely get the word out. Like it was a curse. I felt a twinge of pity for her. People who had put off having kids because they had all the time in the world suddenly had no time. There weren't many kids around, I realized. The world could be in for a whole lot of trouble if its whole work force suddenly aged out of their ablilty to work. My dawning sense of dread was only slightly assuaged by the fact that I was too old to really feel the repercussions of this. I'd be dead before it really got bad. I pressed the button on my phone to call the assistant in my home. I loved it here, I mused, as I waited for her to respond. This retirement community was the perfect place to hide out and live my last decade or two in peace. I pushed the button again. And again. Finally I called the front desk. A harried voice answered. 

"Is it an emergency?" the woman squawked at me, "You should call the police if it is. Nobody's coming! Everyone left!" I sat up. "What did you say?" The dread was spreading through me like a nagging fever in my bones. "They left!" She repeated. "They all realized they don't have much time left to be young; nobody wanted to be stuck here for the last good year they have left!"

"But you're still here," I tried to argue, although I heard the wavering in my own voice. 

"I'll be outta here as soon as I find my purse," she said distractedly. "Sorry, pal. You're on your own."

And then I realized that everything was about to change for the worse, and not just for the fools who tried to make themselves young forever.   I was about to be alone. For the rest of my life. However long it would be.
